description: Adaptive extrapolation automatically selects the best extrapolation model from a set of candidates (linear, polynomial, exponential, etc.) based on the measured data. This data-driven approach reduces bias from choosing an inappropriate model.

The selection is typically done using cross-validation (leave-one-out), information criteria (AIC, BIC), or Bayesian model comparison. The goal is to find the model that best balances fit quality against complexity.
Adaptive methods are particularly valuable when the noise characteristics are unknown or vary across different circuits, making it difficult to choose a single extrapolation model a priori.
how_it_works: Define a set of candidate models: linear, quadratic, cubic, exponential, poly-exponential, etc.
Measure expectation values at multiple noise levels (typically 5+ for reliable selection).
Fit each candidate model to the data.
Score each model using a selection criterion (e.g., leave-one-out cross-validation error, AIC, BIC).
Select the model with the best score and use it for the final extrapolation.
advantages: Adapts to the actual noise behavior in the data
Can improve as more data becomes available
disadvantages: Requires more data points for reliable selection (typically 5+)
Selection criterion may not always choose the best model for extrapolation
Can be sensitive to outliers or measurement errors
More complex implementation than fixed-model methods
